An **elf**, @, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The elf serves as the base monster for the [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") left by [elven](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)") characters, [elf zombies](/wiki/Elf_zombie "Elf zombie") or [elf mummies](/wiki/Elf_mummies "Elf mummies"), and has a much higher base level than other monsters representing a playable race, with a [monster difficulty](/wiki/Monster_difficulty "Monster difficulty") comparable to a [player monster](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster").

Eating an elf [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") of its meat has a 2⁄3 chance of of conveying [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance"), the highest of all [elves](/wiki/Elf_\(monster_attribute\) "Elf (monster attribute)").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 History](#History)
- [4 Variants](#Variants)
  - [4.1 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

Standard elves are [not randomly generated](/wiki/Normal_mechanism "Normal mechanism"). An elf can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into an [elf-lord](/wiki/Elf-lord "Elf-lord").

An elf zombie or elf mummy will leave an aged elf [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") behind upon death;[\[1\]](#cite_note-undead_to_corpse-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-make_corpse-2) player elves that are killed and leave [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") will have an elf corpse atop their grave, unless they were killed by certain monsters or else [stoned](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") or [disintegrated](/wiki/Disintegrate "Disintegrate"). Elves can be generated by zapping a [wand of undead turning](/wiki/Wand_of_undead_turning "Wand of undead turning") at an elf corpse that is *not* left by a elf zombie or mummy, or else selecting elves while reading a [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") [scroll of genocide](/wiki/Scroll_of_genocide "Scroll of genocide").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

An elf will grow up into an elf-noble of the appropriate gender, rather than always becoming a male elf-lord regardless of gender.

## Strategy

Despite being the most reliable source of sleep resistance, elf corpses are usually left by [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") and thus pose a high risk of [food poisoning](/wiki/Food_poisoning "Food poisoning"); however, they can be safely tinned and eaten with a [tinning kit](/wiki/Tinning_kit "Tinning kit").

## History

The elf monster first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"), where it corresponds to the [Elf](/wiki/Elf_\(role\) "Elf (role)") [role](/wiki/Role "Role"). It remains in the game's data after the role is replaced with the [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), where it instead serves as the corresponding monster to

## Variants

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), elves grow up into [Woodland-elves](/wiki/Woodland-elves "Woodland-elves") rather than elf-lords.

## Encyclopedia entry

The Elves sat round the fire upon the grass or upon the sawn rings of old trunks. Some went to and fro bearing cups and pouring drinks; others brought food on heaped plates and dishes.  
"This is poor fare," they said to the hobbits; "for we are lodging in the greenwood far from our halls. If ever you are our guests at home, we will treat you better."  
"It seems to me good enough for a birthday-party," said Frodo. Pippin afterwards recalled little of either food or drink, for his mind was filled with the light upon the elf-faces, and the sound of voices so various and so beautiful that he felt in a waking dream. \[...]  
Sam could never describe in words, nor picture clearly to himself, what he felt or thought that night, though it remained in his memory as one of the chief events of his life. The nearest he ever got was to say: "Well, sir, if I could grow apples like that, I would call myself a gardener. But it was the singing that went to my heart, if you know what I mean."

\[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-undead_to_corpse_1-0) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 147](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L147): *Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-make_corpse_2-0) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 372](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L372): *Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops*

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
For other uses, see Elf.
@ elf
Difficulty 12
Attacks Weapon 1d8
@ elf
Difficulty 12
Attacks

Weapon 1d8

Base level 10
Base experience 216
Speed 12
Base AC 10
Base MR 2
Alignment -3 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable No
Weight 800
Nutritional value 350
Size Medium
Resistances Sleep
Resistances conveyed Sleep (67%)

An elf:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • can see invisible creatures.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is an elf.
  • is strong.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line2309

An elf, @, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. The elf serves as the base monster for the corpse left by elven characters, elf zombies or elf mummies, and has a much higher base level than other monsters representing a playable race, with a monster difficulty comparable to a player monster.

Eating an elf corpse or tin of its meat has a 2⁄3 chance of of conveying sleep resistance, the highest of all elves.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 dNetHack
  • 5 Encyclopedia entry
  • 6 References

Generation

Standard elves are not randomly generated. An elf can grow up into an elf-lord.

An elf zombie or elf mummy will leave an aged elf corpse behind upon death;[1][2] player elves that are killed and leave bones will have an elf corpse atop their grave, unless they were killed by certain monsters or else stoned or disintegrated. Elves can be generated by zapping a wand of undead turning at an elf corpse that is not left by a elf zombie or mummy, or else selecting elves while reading a cursed scroll of genocide.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

An elf will grow up into an elf-noble of the appropriate gender, rather than always becoming a male elf-lord regardless of gender.

Strategy

Despite being the most reliable source of sleep resistance, elf corpses are usually left by undead and thus pose a high risk of food poisoning; however, they can be safely tinned and eaten with a tinning kit.

History

The elf monster first appears in NetHack 3.0.0, where it corresponds to the Elf role. It remains in the game's data after the role is replaced with the Ranger, where it instead serves as the corresponding monster to

Variants

dNetHack

In dNetHack, elves grow up into Woodland-elves rather than elf-lords.

Encyclopedia entry

The Elves sat round the fire upon the grass or upon the sawn rings of old trunks. Some went to and fro bearing cups and pouring drinks; others brought food on heaped plates and dishes.
"This is poor fare," they said to the hobbits; "for we are lodging in the greenwood far from our halls. If ever you are our guests at home, we will treat you better."
"It seems to me good enough for a birthday-party," said Frodo. Pippin afterwards recalled little of either food or drink, for his mind was filled with the light upon the elf-faces, and the sound of voices so various and so beautiful that he felt in a waking dream. [...]
Sam could never describe in words, nor picture clearly to himself, what he felt or thought that night, though it remained in his memory as one of the chief events of his life. The nearest he ever got was to say: "Well, sir, if I could grow apples like that, I would call myself a gardener. But it was the singing that went to my heart, if you know what I mean."

[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]

References

  1. ↑ src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 147: Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts
  2. ↑ src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 372: Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops

An '''elf''', {{white|@}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. The elf serves as the base monster for the [[corpse]] left by [[Elf (starting race)|elven]] characters, [[elf zombie]]s or [[elf mummies]], and has a much higher base level than other monsters representing a playable race, with a [[monster difficulty]] comparable to a [[player monster]].

Eating an elf [[corpse]] or [[tin]] of its meat has a {{frac|2|3}} chance of of conveying [[sleep resistance]], the highest of all [[Elf (monster attribute)|elves]].

==Generation==
Standard elves are [[Normal mechanism|not randomly generated]]. An elf can [[grow up]] into an [[elf-lord]].

An elf zombie or elf mummy will leave an aged elf [[corpse]] behind upon death;{{refsrc|src/mon.c|147|nethack=3.6.7|name="undead_to_corpse"|comment=Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts}}{{refsrc|src/mon.c|372|nethack=3.6.7|name="make_corpse"|comment=Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops}} player elves that are killed and leave [[bones]] will have an elf corpse atop their grave, unless they were killed by certain monsters or else [[Stoning|stoned]] or [[disintegrate]]d. Elves can be generated by zapping a [[wand of undead turning]] at an elf corpse that is ''not'' left by a elf zombie or mummy, or else selecting elves while reading a [[cursed]] [[scroll of genocide]].

{{upcoming|3.7.0|An elf will grow up into an elf-noble of the appropriate gender, rather than always becoming a male elf-lord regardless of gender.}}

==Strategy==
Despite being the most reliable source of sleep resistance, elf corpses are usually left by [[undead]] and thus pose a high risk of [[food poisoning]]; however, they can be safely tinned and eaten with a [[tinning kit]].

==History==
The elf monster first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]], where it corresponds to the [[Elf (role)|Elf]] [[role]]. It remains in the game's data after the role is replaced with the [[Ranger]], where it instead serves as the corresponding monster to

==Variants==
===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], elves grow up into [[Woodland-elves]] rather than elf-lords.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
The Elves sat round the fire upon the grass or upon the sawn rings of old trunks.  Some went to and fro bearing cups and pouring drinks; others brought food on heaped plates and dishes.
"This is poor fare," they said to the hobbits; "for we are lodging in the greenwood far from our halls.  If ever you are our guests at home, we will treat you better."
"It seems to me good enough for a birthday-party," said Frodo. Pippin afterwards recalled little of either food or drink, for his mind was filled with the light upon the elf-faces, and the sound of voices so various and so beautiful that he felt in a waking dream.  [...]
Sam could never describe in words, nor picture clearly to himself, what he felt or thought that night, though it remained in his memory as one of the chief events of his life.  The nearest he ever got was to say: "Well, sir, if I could grow apples like that, I would call myself a gardener.  But it was the singing that went to my heart, if you know what I mean."|[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]}}
